docs.text: it's a fact that a good thriller or action movie doesn't need violence to be good or worth watching .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: all it takes is potential violence to make the audience bite their nails .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: and what kind of violence could be more efficient than a global thermo-nuclear war ?
docs.label: positive

docs.text: and potential violence is the premiss wargames is built upon .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: a computer whiz-kid , david , is usually contended with hacking into the school computer to change his grades .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: but after having read an advertisment for an upcoming computer game , he wants to be the first to play it .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: instead of getting into the computer at protovision software he accidentally comes to the frontgate of norad .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: with the help of jennifer , a girl in his biology class , he starts to play a nice game of nuclear war with wopr , war operation plan response ( a top-notch computer at the time , but now hardly faster than my own computer )
docs.label: positive

docs.text: i remember being 12 and watching this at the cinema .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it was very efficent at giving you a scare in those days and that hasn't changed .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: of course , a nuclear war seemed to be much more of something that could actually happen back in 1983 .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: i wouldn't be surprised if this gave people nightmares .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: i hope it still does since you still hear about school kids hacking into the computers at pentagon .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: broderick and sheedy are just fine as the young teenagers ( although her interest in david remains a mystery ) .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: but the rest of the actors are , by no fault of their own , restricted by the script to play one-dimensional grownups .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: david's parents are the same kind of parents that populate all these college comedies from the 1980s , movies like secret admirer , porky's or zapped and the norad general beringer is straight out of dr . strangelove .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: if for no other reason , you should see this movie to enjoy how far the computer technology has gone since those days .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: david uses the same telephone for calling friends as calling other computers .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the modem is some kind of device that he puts the headset on .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: far from any 56k modem my guess is that it's some kind of 2400 bps modem , the kind of technology you now find at your local technical museum .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the big computer at norad has a lot of flashing lights ( just like those you see on star trek or any old sf-movie ) but it's hardly impressing compared with what you can get today .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: what are the lessons we can learn from wargames ?
docs.label: positive

docs.text: make sure there are no secret backdoors into military computers .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: 2 . thank you , whoever it was , for giving us a graphical user interface when we use our computers !
docs.label: positive
